3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-immigration-election-idUSKCN0Z92RX	Immigration win for Republicans could help Clinton in the end	"
By James Oliphant
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republicans cheered after the U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday thwarted President Barack Obama's plan to offer millions of undocumented immigrants relief from deportation
column2: but any sense of triumph might last only until the November presidential election. If recent history is a guide
column3: the stalled cause of immigration reform could energize Hispanic voters in support of likely Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton
column4: hurting Republican Donald Trump's chances of reaching the White House. Four years ago
column5: Obama
column6: seeking reelection to a second term
column7: made Republican opposition to reform a central theme of his campaign. He ended up swamping his opponent
column9: by almost a 3 to 1 margin among Latino voters
column10: who now make up around 12 percent of the U.S. electorate.Republican hopes for securing a larger share of that vote this election already seemed grim given Trump's vow to deport the estimated 11 million immigrants in the country illegally and to build a wall along the southern U.S. border. Democrats were quick to assail the ruling and voice concern about the fate of the 4 million or so immigrants who were to be shielded from deportation by Obama's executive action. But it was also clear that they believe the high court has handed them a potent weapon to spur Latinos -- the fastest-growing segment of the U.S. electorate -- to vote in greater numbers.The Latino voting bloc is expected to swell to 27.3 million in 2016
column11: up 4 million from 4 years ago. The prospect of Clinton filling the current vacancy on the top court with a liberal-leading justice who could
column14: may galvanize those voters as well. Republicans in Congress have refused to accept Obama's pick for the top court to fill the vacancy left by the death of conservative justice Antonin Scalia in February. The justices' ruling on Thursday sent the question of the legality of Obama's program back to a Texas federal court for trial
column15: leaving open the possibility that the matter could return to the high court on appeal at a later date. The court's decision ""just adds fuel to the fire that's already raging
column17: a Democratic strategist. ""Each of these events raises the intensity and the Latino turnout even more.""In the wake of the ruling
column18: immigration activists vowed payback in November's election and staged protests on Thursday.

column1: FIRING UP LATINO VOTERS
A recent survey by Latino Decisions
column2: a polling firm
column3: showed that about half of the U.S. Hispanic electorate showed greater enthusiasm to vote in 2016 as compared to 2012
column4: with support for Obama's pro-immigrant executive orders running high. ""We should expect similar dynamics this fall
column5: perhaps even more so given the election is likely to determine the ideological direction of the Supreme Court
column7: an analyst for the firm.Given Trump's unpopularity with Latino voters
column8: the question for many Democrats both in and outside the Clinton campaign has been less about attracting the bloc's support and more about making sure it votes in large enough numbers to help offset Trump's expected advantage among white voters.

column1: The court's decision may also help make traditionally Republican states with increasing Hispanic populations such as Arizona more competitive this election
column2: strategists in both parties said. Reed Galen
column3: a Republican strategist in California
column4: said the ruling could boost Democratic hopes in Latino-heavy battleground states such as Nevada
column5: Colorado
column6: and Florida. ""The issue isn't getting [Latino voters] fired up
column7: Galen said. ""It's getting them to show up.""Galen believes there is little his party can do now to mitigate the damage he believes Trump has done to its appeal among Hispanics. A Republican National Committee ""autopsy"" report after Romney's defeat said it was essential for the party to broaden its appeal to Hispanic voters by embracing immigration reform. ""Trump has pushed the envelope on immigration so far for Republicans
column8: I don't know this [decision] is going to be any more damaging
column9: he said. ""The barn's already been blown up.""

column1: But Rev. Samuel Rodriguez
column2: the president of the National Hispanic Christian Leadership Conference
column3: a conservative advocacy group
column4: disagreed. He said Republicans in Congress could still enact reform this year
column5: which would ward off Trump's deportation threat while building stronger ties with Latino voters. ""This is the quintessential green light for Republicans to put their money where their mouth is
column6: Rodriguez said. Many Republicans were careful on Thursday to applaud the court's ruling on the grounds that it curtailed what they viewed as an abuse of executive authority by Obama
column7: without delving into the underlying immigration issues. ""The Constitution is clear: The president is not permitted to write laws -- only Congress is

column16: he said in a statement. He has vowed to reverse Obama's executive actions on immigration as president. (Reporting by James Oliphant; editing by Stuart Grudgings)"

5	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-sitin-idUSKCN0Z91ZS	Latest gun control bid falters in Congress
column2: Democrat sit-in ends	"

column1: By Richard Cowan and Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Another attempt at gun control faltered in the U.S. Congress on Thursday despite outrage at the Orlando massacre
column2: as a proposed ban on firearms sales to people being monitored for links to terrorism barely avoided being killed in the Senate.In a procedural vote
column3: the Senate narrowly rejected an attempt to scrap the plan by Republican Senator Susan Collins to prevent guns getting into the hands of people on two U.S. government terrorism watch lists. But the proposal looked short of the support it would need to advance through the chamber
column4: and Republican leaders said the Senate would switch from debating gun control to other matters until at least after the July 4 holiday.        It was the latest setback for proponents of gun restrictions who have been thwarted for years on Capitol Hill by gun rights defenders and the National Rifle Association.    Frequent efforts at gun control have failed despite anger at mass shootings like the killings at an elementary school in Newtown
column5: Connecticut
column8: last year. ""Eventually this problem will get addressed again one of two ways: We find a breakthrough
column10: or there will be another terrorist attack which will bring us right back to this issue. I hope we can do it without another terrorist attack
column12: a Republican who supported Collins.       A few hours earlier
column13: Democratic lawmakers ended a sit-in protest in the House of Representatives over guns.Fueled by Chinese food and pizzas
column14: dozens of them stayed on the House floor all night
column15: at times bursting into the civil rights anthem ""We Shall Overcome"" before giving up their protest after 25 hours.        ""It's not a struggle that lasts for one day
column20: a Democrat from Georgia and a key figure in the civil rights protests of the 1960s. ""We're going to win the struggle

column1: Dramatic protests by legislators are rare in the U.S. Capitol and the sit-in underscored how sensitive the gun control issue became after this month's Florida attack
column2: the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history.Opinion polls show Americans are increasingly in favor of more restrictions on guns in a country with more than 310 million weapons
column3: about one for every citizen.     ORLANDO ATTACK

column1: After a gunman pledging allegiance to Islamic State fatally shot 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando
column2: some senators had seen resistance to gun restrictions softening because the issue had partly become one of national security.But Collins' measure received only 52 votes in the 100-seat Senate test vote
column3: short of the 60 votes that would be needed for  approval in future Senate procedural votes. While her plan could be revived next month
column4: it is unclear if she has the momentum to overcome pro-gun rights forces in Congress who argue that gun control measures in Congress have been too restrictive and trample on the constitutional right to bear arms. Four other gun control measures failed earlier this week.             Collins
column5: a Maine lawmaker
column6: wants to forbid gun sales to anyone on the U.S. government's ""No Fly List"" for terrorism suspects or the ""Selectee List"" of people who receive extra security screening at airports.        Despite the lack of legislation
column7: the gun debate has stirred passions. The House Democrats' sit-in brought an outpouring of grass-roots activity.

column1: Jennifer Hoppe
column2: deputy director of Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America
column3: said that in less than 24 hours from Wednesday
column4: about 130
column5: 000 calls were made from supporters of gun control to members of Congress.First lady Michelle Obama backed the House Democrats' protest.""We have grieved for too many children and wept for too many families after shootings. Chicago. Tucson. Newtown. Charleston. Orlando. #Enough
column6: she wrote on Twitter on Thursday.The Democrats were seeking votes on legislation to expand background checks for gun purchases
column7: as well as measures to curb the sale of weapons to people on government watch lists            Republicans allied with the NRA gun rights group say that while they want to combat terrorism
column8: they represent constituents who believe firmly in the constitutional right to bear arms. ""It's a tough issue. For people like myself
column9: who come from a hunting and fishing state
column12: a conservative Utah Republican who voted against Collins.             (Additional reporting by Richard Cowan

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-usa-whitehouse-idUSKCN0ZA0OR	Obama briefed after Britain votes to leave EU	"
By Roberta Rampton
| SAN FRANCISCO
SAN FRANCISCO U.S. President Barack Obama was briefed by his advisers late on Thursday on Britain's vote to leave the European Union
column2: a result that he had argued passionately against during an April visit to London.Obama
column3: who was scheduled to deliver remarks to global entrepreneurs at a conference at Stanford University at 10:45 a.m. PDT (1:45 p.m. ET/1745 GMT)
column4: was dining out at an upscale restaurant with a small group of top venture capitalists and Silicon Valley entrepreneurs as the results for the ""leave"" campaign began to roll in.The group at San Francisco's Twenty-Five Lusk included John Doerr of Kleiner Perkins Caufield Byers
column5: and LinkedIn's Reid Hoffman.Obama dined for more than two hours
column6: departing shortly after British networks called the referendum for the ""leave"" campaign
column7: and markets plunged. A White House official said Obama had been briefed on the returns and would ""continue to be updated by his team as the situation warrants.""

column1: We expect the president will have an opportunity to speak to Prime Minister Cameron over the course of the next day
column2: and we will release further comment as soon as appropriate
column3: the official said in a brief statement to reporters.Obama traveled to London in April at the request of Cameron
column4: whom he calls a friend
column5: exhorting Britons to stay in the EU
column6: an unusual intervention that was denounced as meddling by those in the ""leave"" campaign.

column1: Obama also warned that leaving the EU would put Britain at the ""back of the queue"" for a trade deal with the United States.Obama's term in the White House ends on Jan. 20
column2: 2017. His former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton
column3: the presumptive Democratic candidate in the Nov. 8 election
column4: had also said she hoped the UK would stay in the EU.

column1: The presumptive Republican nominee - real estate magnate Donald Trump - had taken the opposite stance
column2: saying he thought the UK should leave. Trump
column3: in Scotland on Friday to reopen a golf resort
column4: told reporters that Britons ""took back control of their country"" by voting to leave the European Union. (Reporting by Roberta Rampton; Additional reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Howard Goller; Editing by Clarence Fernandez)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-socialmedia-idUSKCN0Z92LQ	Democrat gun control sit-in sparks social media sensation	"
By Amy Tennery

A blackout of television cameras in the U.S. House Representatives during the Democrats' gun control sit-in may have spurred public interest in the protest as it forced the demonstrators to use social media to broadcast their message.Democrats leapt on Facebook Live and Twitter's Periscope after the cameras
column2: controlled by the House
column3: went dark Wednesday when presiding House officer and Republican Representative Ted Poe declared the chamber not in order during the protest.As Democrats took to alternative forms of video broadcasting
column4: their message gained tremendous momentum from social media. On Twitter
column5: the hashtags #NoBillNoBreak and #HoldTheFloor have been tweeted at least 1.4 million times.Of the roughly 20 members of Congress who remained at the sit-in overnight
column6: 19 of them used Facebook Live for a total combined viewership of 3 million.""It really connected with people out there
column7: Congressman Scott Peters told Reuters. ""This whole phenomenon with [live video] struck a nerve.""Peters used the application Periscope
column8: which is connected to the social media platform Twitter

column1: Without that
column2: think about it
column3: it would have been a caucus meeting where we talk to ourselves
column4: he added. In remarks Wednesday outside the Capitol
column5: House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi praised how her party harnessed social media.""Without you and without the technology of Periscope [the sit-in] would just be a debate in the Halls of Congress unrecorded because they turned off the microphones
column6: Pelosi said. ""But we raised our voices. They turned off the cameras and we went to Periscope.""

column1: Congressman Mark Takano
column2: who began posting live videos from the chamber to his Facebook page Wednesday afternoon and continued to throughout the night
column3: said the social media video helped him connect with constituents.""Once I got started with the live streaming I didn't feel like I could let down the people who were following me
column4: said Takano. ""It was a way to push out a message.""Even C-SPAN
column5: which typically broadcasts footage recorded by the House cameras
column6: picked up live video from four different members of Congress roughly two hours after the House cameras shut down
column7: according to communications director Howard Mortman. It marked the first time the channel broadcast a live social media feed from the House floor.

column1: Something interesting is happening with Facebook Live that's bringing more openness to the political process
column2: said Mark Zuckerberg
column3: CEO of Facebook
column4: in a post to his social media profile Thursday.""It's a way to share anything you want with the world using just your phone."" (Reporting By Amy Tennery; additional reporting by Angela Moon in New York and Susan Cornwell in Washington; Editing by Andrew Hay)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-democrats-idUSKCN0Z92N8	Democrats say gun defeat in Congress could help on campaign trail	"
By Andy Sullivan
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Democrats in Congress ended a 25-hour sit-in on the floor of the House of Representatives where they have been countless times before: short of the votes needed to tighten U.S. gun laws.But many see their latest defeat as a prelude to victory in the Nov. 8 elections.Spurred by the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history
column2: Democrats are showing a new willingness to make gun laws a top issue in Washington and on the campaign trail
column3: defying powerful lobbying groups like the National Rifle Association that have helped make the United States the most gun-friendly country in the developed world.The effort is not likely to change federal firearms laws this year
column4: as Republicans who control Congress have shown little interest in proposals that they say weaken Americans' constitutional right to bear arms.But Democrats and their allies say that defeat now on Capitol Hill could help them win control of the White House and both chambers of Congress in the Nov. 8 elections. That is a shift from previous elections when Democrats have downplayed the issue on the campaign trail.""The tide has turned
column5: and Republicans ignore this issue at their own peril
column7: a former Democratic congressional aide. Hillary Clinton
column9: talks frequently in her campaign about banning military-style assault rifles and expanding background checks -- a marked contrast to President Barack Obama
column10: who avoided talk of guns during his 2008 and 2012 elections.In Congress
column11: Democrats have resorted to confrontational tactics to force gun votes since June 12
column12: when a gunman killed 49 people at a Florida nightclub. Senator Chris Murphy's 15-hour speech in the Senate last week forced five votes this week on measures that would make it harder for terrorism suspects to buy guns
column13: though none have advanced.In the House
column14: Democrats occupied the chamber for 25 hours in an unsuccessful attempt to force votes on terrorism suspects and expanding background checks for gun buyers.Republican pollster Kellyanne Conway said Democrats' willingness to talk about guns reflects the party becoming more liberal
column15: not a change in public sentiment.

column3: said Democratic strategist Hank Sheinkopf.

column1: There's a potentially a good electoral outcome for Democrats out of this. They will probably pick up seats

column4: who hopes to unseat Republican U.S. Senator Marco Rubio in gun-friendly Florida
column5: said during the House sit-in that gun rights groups like the NRA are ""largely responsible"" for the country's 32
column6: 000 annual gun deaths. ""This passion you're seeing is what's needed to get people to wake up
column7: he said on the House floor.The NRA did not respond to a request for comment.

column2: while 23 percent support minimal rules. Support runs higher for specific proposals
column3: like imposing background checks on all gun buyers. (bit.ly/28U7CA7)But intensity has been a sticking point for gun control advocates. The NRA has been able to mobilize supporters who are willing to vote for or against a candidate solely because of their position on guns
column4: while gun-control supporters typically consider other issues as well
column5: such as abortion and the environment.""Anytime the Democrats start a gun movement
column8: who has worked for centrist Democratic candidates. ""I can't imagine it's changing.""Shootings in Newtown
column14: others say. ""Mass shootings are highly visible
column15: and force people to pay attention and realize that we have a problem that isn't going to be solved by more guns
column17: a Democratic strategist in Atlanta who worked on Obama's 2012 campaign.The gun-control lobbying group Everytown for Gun Safety says its members generated 245
column19: and brought hundreds of its members to Congress to press for action during the debate.""I've been in the fight for a number of years and I've never seen anything like this
column21: an advocate with the group who was wounded during the 2007 Virginia Tech mass shooting. (Additional reporting by Ginger Gibson and Jonathan Allen; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-usa-whitehouse-idUSKCN0Z92E2	White House threatens to veto Republicans' Zika funding plan	"
By Roberta Rampton and Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The White House on Thursday threatened to veto the $1.1 billion approved by the U.S. House of Representatives to fight the Zika virus
column2: blasting the measure for short-changing the administration's $1.9 billion funding request.The Republican-controlled House approved the funding deal early Thursday morning after reaching a deal with both House and Senate Republicans.White House spokesman Eric Schultz said the bill ""falls far short"" of the amount of money recommended by health officials to address the spread of the Zika virus.""This is a bill that would steal money from other critically important public health priorities
column3: Schultz told reporters at a briefing. ""We urge Republicans to stop turning this into a political football
column4: and to actually get to work to come up with proposals that will serve the American people.""The administration also criticized the bill for limiting contraception access for women seeking to prevent Zika
column5: which can be spread through unprotected sex.

column1: The Senate is expected to vote on funding to combat the Zika virus next week
column2: but the bill faces an uncertain fate in the chamber
column3: where the Democratic minority has more power to stop legislation. Democratic leader Harry Reid has declared his opposition.Republican House Speaker Paul Ryan urged the Senate to move on the bill.""It is a responsible plan that assures the administration will continue to have the needed resources to protect the public
column4: Ryan said. Republicans said the deal included funding for fiscal years 2016 and 2017.

column1: If the Senate approved the bill
column2: a White House veto would likely mean that lawmakers would not take up the issue until the House and Senate return from their July 4 holiday recess - well into the U.S. summer season. The House has already adjourned for holiday and the Senate is expected to start its recess next Friday.      Democrats have been urging Republicans for months to agree to more Zika funding
column3: and the Obama administration has already reprogrammed nearly $600 million that had been set aside to fight Ebola.House Democrats said they could not go along with the deal because of $750 million in budget cuts elsewhere that the Republicans want to use to pay for the Zika spending.

column1: Senate Democrats also voiced displeasure
column2: clouding the outlook for it passing.""A narrowly partisan proposal that cuts off women's access to birth control
column3: shortchanges veterans and rescinds Obamacare funds to cover the cost is not a serious response to the threat from the Zika virus
column4: Reid said. According to House Appropriations Committee Chairman Hal Rogers
column5: $543 million of the $1.1 billion would come from unspent funds set aside for implementing Obamacare in U.S. territories
column6: while $107 million would come from unused funds to fight another virus
column7: Ebola. Another $100 million would come from unused administrative funds at the Department of Health and Human Services
column10: Ayesha Rascoe; Editing by Susan Heavey and Bernard Orr)"
